newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks end mixed despite key index gains.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks end mixed despite key index gains.

* Toronto's key index closed higher on Monday but the broader market ended mixed, dragged down by a sell-off in golds and base metals. * 83 million shares traded worth C$1.3 billion.
Toronto's key equities index closed higher on Monday, aided by Friday's strength, but the broader market closed mixed as investors sold off Bre-X Minerals Ltd and other mining issues.
The Toronto Stock Exchange's 300 Composite Index rose 23.49 points to 5840.78. Trading was moderate at 82.9 million shares worth C$1.34 billion.
"I think we carried over from the rally we got late on Friday in New York," said ScotiaMcLeod senior vice-president Fred Ketchen. The Dow Jones Industrial Average soared 48 points in late trading.
Big mutual fund managers decided Toronto fell far enough last week and re-entered the market, snapping up bank stocks and conglomerates, Ketchen said.
Despite that optimism, investors still see "a negative side surrounding the gold sector," Ketchen said.
Of Toronto's 14 sub-indices, only golds and base metals tumbled, while the rest soared. Heavyweight conglomerates rose most, followed by financial institutions, media and forestry.
Declines edged out advances 456 to 452, while 170 issues traded flat.
--- HOT STOCKS ---

* Bre-X Minerals Ltd topped Toronto actives, dropping 0.66 to 2.52 on 15 million shares. Institutional investors were spooked by media reports that appeared to put the gold prospector in a more negative light.
* Bank of Nova Scotia gained 0.90 to reach 51.75.
